image.altText: Portrait of Shane Rattenbury sitting on a small wall with bushland down a mountain behind him.

props.synopsis: The ACT election saw the Greens go from six seats in the Legislative Assembly to three, with a fourth possible, but the swing against them was smaller than it appeared with the result being the party's third-best in ACT history.

title.children: ACT Greens still have 'very strong base' despite losing nearly half their Legislative Assembly seats

image.altText: A man in a suit speaks into multiple microphones.

props.synopsis: Re-elected MLA Jeremy Hanson says the party's seventh-straight election loss was "very disappointing", as conversations continue about Elizabeth Lee's leadership.

title.children: Jeremy Hanson confirms he will make bid for Canberra Liberals leadership, says the party has 'gone backwards'

image.altText: People walking across a courtyard surrounded by buildings.

props.synopsis: Vice-chancellor Stephen Parker says the University of Canberra is "spending beyond its means" and needs to save about $50 million in recurrent expenditure by the end of next year.

title.children: University of Canberra to cut 200 jobs as part of 'urgent and significant' cost-saving measures

image.altText: King Charles III chats with owner of alpaca.

props.synopsis: King Charles III and Queen Camilla have landed in Australia's capital as they begin their second official day of royal engagements.

title.children: King Charles III and Queen Camilla greet alpaca, given Tim Tams in Canberra as protester arrested

image.altText: Cages at a dog pound.

props.synopsis: Pet owners are urged to protect their dogs from the deadly parvovirus by keeping their vaccinations up to date.

title.children: 'A horrible disease': Queanbeyan Pound euthanases 21 dogs after outbreak of canine parvovirus

image.altText: Mick Gentleman looking sombre.

props.synopsis: While the ACT election has been called in favour of Labor, the exact make-up of the next Legislative Assembly isn't yet certain and there is one seat still up for grabs.

title.children: One seat still in doubt in ACT election as Greens claim third

image.altText: A woman stands in front of microphones.

props.synopsis: The leader of the Canberra Liberals has expressed agreement with suggestions that some in her party would rather wage internal ideological battles than secure electoral victory in the ACT.

title.children: Canberra Liberals leader agrees party too far to the right following ACT election loss

image.altText: Thomas Emerson on election night.

props.synopsis: For the first time in 20 years, the ACT has elected independent members to parliament. Thomas Emerson and Fiona Carrick have become the first independents elected to the ACT Legislative Assembly since 2001.

title.children: The independent wave hits the ACT as Andrew Barr promises a 'progressive and stable' crossbench

image.altText: Edith Chow reads a map on her bike

props.synopsis: With entrants describing it as a treasure hunt race or chess on wheels, the Australian Mountain Bike Orienteering Championships in Canberra attracted more than 200 participants of all ages and abilities over the weekend.

title.children: 'Like chess on wheels': How mountain bike orienteering is breaking new ground

image.altText: Lidia Thorpe yelling wearing a fur cloak.

props.synopsis: The senator said she felt she had no other way to convey her message after not being granted an audience with the king.

title.children: Dutton says Lidia Thorpe should resign on principle after royal interruption

image.altText: A man at a podium in an empty auditorium.

props.synopsis: Graduating students say a speech by former union boss Joe de Bruyn "took a hard-right turn" as he voiced anti-abortion views during a ceremony at the Australian Catholic University in Melbourne.

title.children: Students walk out during 'shocking' anti-abortion speech by former union boss at university graduation

image.altText: Composite image showing Charlie Stevens and Dhirren Randhawa.

props.synopsis: The teenager who struck and killed South Australian Police Commissioner Grant Steven's son at Schoolies celebrations last year has been handed a suspended sentence.

title.children: Teenager avoids jail over death of Charlie Stevens in hit-and-run crash

image.altText: Kamala Harris sitting at a table with her hands folded, looking to her right.

props.synopsis: The Biden administration's staunch support of Israel was already threatening the Democrats' support from Arab-Americans in the key battleground state of Michigan, but for some in the community the escalating situation in Lebanon is the final straw.

title.children: A third-party candidate could cost Kamala Harris votes in this key state. It might be enough to hand victory to Donald Trump

image.altText: A 'sold' real estate sign sits next to a white fence outside a home

props.synopsis: The minister throws her weight behind a Business Council proposal for states to replace stamp duties with land tax.

title.children: Stamp duty 'a bad tax' that distorts the market, housing minister says, welcoming shift to land tax

image.altText: Russian Bakhram Murtazaliev hits Australian boxer Tim Tszyu in their IBF junior middleweight world title fight.

props.synopsis: Tim Tszyu says he is "willing to die" when he steps into the ring. In a sport where that is a sombre possibility, the gritty Australian warrior needs to be protected from his own instincts, writes Paul Kennedy.

title.children: Tim Tszyu will never be the same after his latest beating, and it shouldn't have been allowed to happen

image.altText: A microchip.

props.synopsis: Silicon chips are now fundamental to modern life, incorporated into every facet of electronics and driving up share prices on Wall Street. Taiwan has dominated semiconductor production but finds itself at the centre of a geopolitical, and technological, contest.

title.children: Taiwan's chip domination the real prize in East-West divide

image.altText: Vladimir Putin and Kim Jong Un

props.synopsis: Ukraine releases a video, allegedly taken by a Russian soldier, showing North Koreans collecting Russian military uniforms and equipment.

title.children: About 11,000 North Korean soldiers are being trained in Russia, Ukrainian officials claim

image.altText: A Qantas worker wearing a high-vis vest wipes down an engine that has a red kangaroo logo on it.

props.synopsis: After Qantas was ordered by the Federal Court to compensate 1,700 former workers, an industrial relations lawyer says the airline will still have saved millions of dollars once it pays its legal bills, ex-employees, and any extra penalties.

title.children: Qantas saved $580m by sacking hundreds of ground crew. They won't get anything close to that in compensation

image.altText: A sparse new kitchen, with blue cupboards , white bench top, polished concrete floor and wooden shelving.

props.synopsis: Rebuilding a home exactly as it was doesn't always make sense for those impacted by natural disasters. Queensland is helping home owners retrofit to be more resilient.

title.children: More Australians are retrofitting their homes to be natural disaster 'proof'. Here's what they're doing

image.altText: A headshot of a man fixing his glasses with both hands.

props.synopsis: The provocative Australian documentarian talks us through his latest adventure.

title.children: John Safran's latest adventure? Living in Kanye West's abandoned mansion for a week

image.altText: Doongmabulla Springs

props.synopsis: Mining giant Adani has accused scientists of being used by anti-coal campaigners after they published new research highlighting risks of coal mining to the Doongmabulla Springs.

title.children: Adani launches attack on scientists who revealed evidence of mining risks to protected ancient springs

image.altText: Meta promoting its new facial recognition features

props.synopsis: Meta's new experiment is part of the tech giant's cautious return to the use of facial recognition, having backed away from the technology amid a series of costly lawsuits.

title.children: Meta is rolling out facial recognition to combat 'relentless' celebrity endorsement scams

image.altText: A jockey lies on his back with his legs in the air as his horse starts to bolt away.

props.synopsis: One of the favourites of the Cox Plate is unlikely to run on Saturday after throwing jockey James McDonald during trackwork, before racing around the track without the rider.

title.children: Cox Plate frontrunner 'unlikely' to race after throwing jockey in dramatic trackwork session

image.altText: Peter Dutton wears glasses and looks up while sitting in the House of Representatives.

props.synopsis: The differences between Labor and the Coalition's plans to ease the housing crisis are becoming clearer, with the opposition betting that Australians prefer detached dwellings in outer suburbs rather than high-density housing.

title.children: The opposition is betting on detached homes in outer suburbs as the election fight over housing policies shapes up

image.altText: A front on head and shoulders shot of  man in a suit with a blurred green background.

props.synopsis: All the posts have been deleted or had their viewing permissions changed since the ABC put questions to the party and each candidate.

title.children: One Nation candidates are posting conspiracy theories about QAnon and man-made storms on social media

image.altText: Flames surround the firing of a missile from a military ship

props.synopsis: Defence Industry Minister Pat Conroy confirms a deal to buy medium and long-range American missiles amid what he calls "the greatest arms race in our region since 1945".

title.children: Australia reveals plan for $7b missile purchase from US

image.altText: Emissions are seen from a factory at Broadwater in far northern New South Wales.

props.synopsis: The federal government may push back the release of its 2035 emissions reduction target from early next year.

title.children: Australia's next big climate target might be delayed by months

image.altText: Australia batters Steve Smith, Marnus Labuschagne and Usman Khawaj talk at a training session.

props.synopsis: Steve Smith is happy to be moving back to number four for this summer's Test series against India, and Marnus Labuschagne and Usman Khawaja will be too.

title.children: Steve Smith says Test teammates 'hated me up top' as he prepares to return to favoured batting spot

image.altText: A woman looks sternly at the camera.

props.synopsis: Crystal's baby was born in jail while she waited for her case to be processed. Her wait for justice is not uncommon in the NT, where the courts are so backlogged that unprecedented numbers of people are being left to languish on remand.

title.children: Crystal's newborn son spent his first 10 months in prison, while she waited almost a year on remand

image.altText: Sean Combs, wearing a black jacket, looks neutrally off camera in front of plastered logos.

props.synopsis: Four men and three women join the list of accusers claiming they were assaulted by the hip hop mogul, with some claiming other entertainment figures were involved.

title.children: New 'Diddy' sex abuse lawsuits claim unnamed celebrities were involved in assaults

image.altText: A view of a harbour in Jeju Island in South Korea

props.synopsis: The South Korean island of Jeju is offering newlyweds the chance to rent apartments for less than $30 a month in the hope it might encourage them to have children.

title.children: South Korean tourism island offers rent for $28 a month to boost fertility rates

image.altText: Close up of blueberries in hands.

props.synopsis: If you're a blueberry fan, now is the time to stock up. Prices have dropped in supermarkets across Australia as seasonal supply levels peak to astronomical heights.

title.children: From $20 to $2.50 a punnet. Why blueberry prices have dropped across Australia

image.altText: a photo of a man in a suit speaking with a building in the background

props.synopsis: As the NT government brings tough new public drinking measures to parliament, an independent politician is warning Aboriginal people sleeping rough to consider leaving town centres.

title.children: New drinking and bail laws could end with more Aboriginal people in jail, says elder and politician

image.altText: Leaupepe Lasa Aiono wearing a yellow bandana on head looking at camera whilst holding two Chinese cabbages in hands.

props.synopsis: One of the key themes for the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting this week is "a resilient environment" — and King Charles has long promoted climate change mitigation.

title.children: Samoan culinary gems served to world leaders to include breadfruit and misiluki bananas

image.altText: Three colourful pamphlets for the Perth Royal Show

props.synopsis: Days after an ABC investigation uncovered a man with a record of serious historical child sex offences running a stall at the Perth Royal Show, a former police officer reveals she sent organisers a letter outlining concerns around safety and working with children check requirements.

title.children: Ex-police officer raised red flags over Perth Royal Show child safety well before paedophile seen running stall
